job_description:
Design novel MEMS system coupling ultrasound and micro-fluidics 

What you will do

Within imecâs Sensor and Actuator Technology department, our teamâs activities focus on the development of novel applications using transducers, sensors and actuators using MEMS technology. The team is working on the design and characterization of the devices itself as well as the full system analysis until the creation of demos. In this job you will work on these novel technologies and systems. You will collaborate closely with the biomedical, process technology, and ASIC teams. This interaction will enable the natural evolution of the currently developed MEMS technologies and devices towards their application. Materials selection, technology parameter definition, modeling of novel physical phenomena as well as technological variability will be key for this successful transition.

In this role, your main responsibilities will be:

  • You will design novel MEMS system coupling ultrasound and micro-fluidics using existing technologies and technologies under development. More specifically, you will work on the design of ultrasound transducers to generate force on biological medium in order to control droplets, to move fluid in a channel or to control cell for sorting. 
  • You will participate to the characterization of the designed devices in order to update your models.
  • You will build acousto-fluidic set-up in collaboration of the life science department to demonstrate the application. 
  • You will maintain a high standard of literature knowledge to support the design activities.
  • You will collaborate with specialists from our cross-disciplinary design and technology teams.
  • You will follow up on customer projects
  • You will be involved in the definition of industrial as well as public funded projects.
  • You will contribute to the creation of a long-term vision and strategy for the group. You will generate patents and publish in international journals.
  • You will mentor Master internship students and PhD students to leverage the work
